natural problem: What is the smallest possible value of the sum $\lvert x + 2\rvert + \lvert x + 4\rvert + \lvert x + 5\rvert$?
natural solution: \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) + (x + 4) + (x + 5) = x + 7.\]For $x \ge -2,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = (x + 2) + (x + 4) + (x + 5) = 3x + 11.\]Thus, the function is decreasing on $(-\infty,4]$ and increasing on $[4,\infty),$ so the minimum value occurs at $x = -4,$ which is $\boxed{3}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "LEAST a. \<exists>x. abs(x + 2) + abs(x + 4) + abs(x + 5) = a"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the smallest possible value of the sum $\lvert x + 2\rvert + \lvert x + 4\rvert + \lvert x + 5\rvert$? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 For $x \le -5,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) - (x + 4) - (x + 5) = -3x - 11.\]For $-5 \le x \le -4,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) - (x + 4) + (x + 5) = -x - 1.\]For $-4 \le x \le -2,$
 \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) + (x + 4) + (x + 5) = x + 7.\]For $x \ge -2,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = (x + 2) + (x + 4) + (x + 5) = 3x + 11.\]Thus, the function is decreasing on $(-\infty,4]$ and increasing on $[4,\infty),$ so the minimum value occurs at $x = -4,$ which is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "LEAST a. \<exists>x. abs(x + 2) + abs(x + 4) + abs(x + 5) = a"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the smallest possible value for the expression $|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5|$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "(LEAST s. \<exists> x. abs(x + 2) + abs(x + 4) + abs(x + 5) = s) = 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the smallest possible value of the sum $\lvert x + 2\rvert + \lvert x + 4\rvert + \lvert x + 5\rvert$? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 For $x \le -5,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) - (x + 4) - (x + 5) = -3x - 11.\]For $-5 \le x \le -4,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) - (x + 4) + (x + 5) = -x - 1.\]For $-4 \le x \le -2,$
 \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = -(x + 2) + (x + 4) + (x + 5) = x + 7.\]For $x \ge -2,$ \[|x + 2| + |x + 4| + |x + 5| = (x + 2) + (x + 4) + (x + 5) = 3x + 11.\]Thus, the function is decreasing on $(-\infty,4]$ and increasing on $[4,\infty),$ so the minimum value occurs at $x = -4,$ which is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "(LEAST s. \<exists> x. abs(x + 2) + abs(x + 4) + abs(x + 5) = s) = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the smallest possible value of the sum of the absolute values of $x+2$, $x+4$, and $x+5$. The final answer is $3$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes x :: real
shows  "3 \<le> abs (x + 2) + abs (x + 4) + abs (x + 5)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

theorem 
fixes x :: real
shows  "3 \<le> abs (x + 2) + abs (x + 4) + abs (x + 5)"
 proof-
